    LinesIntersect2D(Point2D, Point2D, Point2D, Point2D, Boolean, Boolean, Boolean, ref Point2D, Double)

    This method detects if two line segments (or lines) intersect, and, if so, the point of intersection. Use the firstIsSegment and secondIsSegment parameters to set whether the intersection point must be on the first and second line segments. Setting these both to true means you are doing a line-segment to line-segment intersection. Setting one of them to true means you are doing a line to line-segment intersection test, and so on. Note: If two line segments are coincident, then no intersection is detected (there are actually infinite intersection points).

    Declaration
    public static bool LinesIntersect2D(Point2D ptStart0, Point2D ptEnd0, Point2D ptStart1, Point2D ptEnd1, bool firstIsSegment, bool secondIsSegment, bool coincidentEndPointCollisions, ref Point2D pIntersectionPt, double epsilon)
    Parameters
    Type Name Description
    Point2D ptStart0

    The first point of the first line segment.
    Point2D ptEnd0

    The second point of the first line segment.
    Point2D ptStart1

    The first point of the second line segment.
    Point2D ptEnd1

    The second point of the second line segment.
    Boolean firstIsSegment

    Set this to true to require that the intersection point be on the first line segment.
    Boolean secondIsSegment

    Set this to true to require that the intersection point be on the second line segment.
    Boolean coincidentEndPointCollisions

    Set this to true to enable collisions if the line segments share an endpoint
    Point2D pIntersectionPt

    This is set to the intersection point if an intersection is detected.
    Double epsilon
    Returns
    Type Description
    Boolean

    True if an intersection is detected, false otherwise.

    SmartIncircle(Point2D, Point2D, Point2D, Point2D)

    Requirements:

    1. a,b and c form a triangle.
    2. a and d is know to be on opposite side of bc 
                     a
            +
           / \
          /   \
        b/     \c
        +-------+ 
       /    B    \  
      /           \
      Facts: d has to be in area B to have a chance to be inside the circle formed by a,b and c d is outside B if orient2d(a,b,d) or orient2d(c,a,d) is CW This preknowledge gives us a way to optimize the incircle test
    Declaration
    public static bool SmartIncircle(Point2D pa, Point2D pb, Point2D pc, Point2D pd)
    Parameters
    Type Name Description
    Point2D pa

    triangle point, opposite d
    Point2D pb

    triangle point
    Point2D pc

    triangle point
    Point2D pd

    point opposite a
    Returns
    Type Description
    Boolean

    true if d is inside circle, false if on circle edge
